P.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially granted membership in NATO, as confirmed by a formal announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be ratified by all current NATO member states, and Ukraine must fulfill all necessary criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

para_P.title: Will Ukraine become a NATO member before 2030?
para_P.body: This question will be answered affirmatively if Ukraine gains official NATO membership before January 1, 2030, as verified by an official statement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be approved by all current NATO member countries, and Ukraine must meet all the necessary requirements for membership as specified in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not qualify as membership. If a membership application is approved but not ratified by all member countries, the question will be answered negatively.

P.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially granted membership in NATO, as confirmed by a formal announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be ratified by all current NATO member states, and Ukraine must fulfill all necessary criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled and held in a country that is currently under international sanctions recognized by at least one major international body (such as the United Nations or the European Union). The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the event, and the event must be confirmed by the official Formula 1 calendar or an official announcement from the Formula 1 organization. Temporary events or exhibitions do not count, and the Grand Prix must be part of the regular Formula 1 season. If the country is removed from sanctions before the event, the resolution will be No.

metadata.source_question: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

para_P.title: By 2025, will a Formula 1 race take place in a nation currently facing international sanctions?
para_P.body: This question will be answered with Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 race is officially planned and conducted in a nation that is presently under international sanctions acknowledged by at least one significant international entity (such as the United Nations or the European Union). The sanctions must be active at the time of the race, and the event must be validated by the official Formula 1 calendar or an official statement from the Formula 1 organization. Temporary events or exhibitions are excluded, and the race must be part of the standard Formula 1 season. If the sanctions on the nation are lifted before the race, the answer will be No.

P.title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?

The sanctions must be in effect at the time of the event, and the event must be confirmed by the official Formula 1 calendar or an official announcement from the Formula 1 organization. P.title: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. The development of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by a reputable source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies.

metadata.source_question: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?

para_P.title: Will the emergence of a new infectious disease lead to the creation of nuclear biocontainment technologies by 2030?
para_P.body: This question will be answered with Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a novel infectious disease appears that prompts the creation and implementation of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'novel infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not been previously identified in humans and can spread from person to person, causing an outbreak. The creation of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially acknowledged and reported by a credible source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The technologies must be functional and intended for use against the novel infectious disease, and not just proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are created for multiple diseases, the question will still be answered with Yes if the novel infectious disease is included within the scope of the technologies.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?

A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. The development of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by a reputable source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies.
